data.text: A tip-off from desperate parents led Turkish police to swoop on three British teenagers as they allegedly travelled to join Islamic State, The Times has learnt.

Two 17-year-old Muslim schoolboys from the Pakistani community in Brent, northwest London, and a 19-year-old man were intercepted in Istanbul at the weekend and swiftly returned to England. They were questioned by counterterrorism officials last night.

Quick action by the parents of the younger boys, when the pair did not return home after Friday prayers, thwarted the latest alleged attempt by young Britons to join the terrorist group, sources said.

It came two days after Britain’s most senior police officer reassured the families of three runaway schoolgirls from east London that they would not be prosecuted if they returned home from Syria. More than 600 British jihadists have left for Syria and Iraq, many enticed by slick propaganda on social media. In an apparent attempt to evade detection, the trio did not fly direct to Istanbul, but travelled via Barcelona. Their ability to reach Turkey will again raise questions over whether airlines and border officials are doing enough to vet unaccompanied youngsters.

The teenagers are believed to have taken a flight to Spain from Luton airport early on Friday. They then travelled from Barcelona to Istanbul’s second airport, Sabiha Gökçen, where they were intercepted. Scotland Yard’s counterterrorism command had linked the younger teenagers with the man of 19 before handing the trio’s names and descriptions to the Turkish authorities. They were returned to Britain on an evening flight on Saturday, and arrested shortly after 11pm.

The parents of the younger two were understood to be with them at a police station in central London last night. The three teenagers were questioned on suspicion of preparation of terrorist acts contrary to Section 5 of the Terrorism Act 2006. They were all later released on bail.

The two youths of 17, who are thought not to be related, are said to be naive. They are believed to be from working-class families — one father works in the railway industry and the other in restaurants. Their connection with the older teenager was not clear.

The swift intervention was in stark contrast to the case of the missing east London girls. Shamima Begum, 15, Amira Abase, 15, and Kadiza Sultana, 16, flew direct to Istanbul before travelling by road into Syria. They are believed to have reached the Islamic State stronghold of Raqqa despite a public appeal urging their return.

The Metropolitan police were criticised after it emerged that the girls had been questioned in December when their friend, Sharmeena Begum, 15, travelled to Syria. All four attended Bethnal Green Academy. Letters intended for the girls’ parents did not reach them because police handed them to the girls themselves, instead of sending them through the post. Keith Vaz, chairman of the Commons home affairs select committee, which questioned the officers last week, said he was pleased that on this occasion it took only 48 hours to bring the youths back to Britain.

“This shows that there is a greater awareness among the public and parents as well as the Metropolitan police and Turkish authorities of the need with these cases to move with great speed, following the willingness of the [schoolgirls’] families to speak out publicly.
“If this case had gone the same way then it would have been a great propaganda coup for Isis. They should all be commended.”

The questioning of the male teenagers came after Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe, the Metropolitan police commissioner, and an assistant commissioner, Mark Rowley, told a parliamentary committee last week that the missing schoolgirls would not be treated as criminals if they returned home. Legal experts said that the position of the schoolgirls could differ from men as they are thought to be intent on becoming “jihadi brides” and are less likely to join any armed conflict.

In another development yesterday, the man who is alleged to have smuggled the three girls into Syria was named as Mohammed al-Rashed, 28, a Syrian citizen and a former dentist. He is said to have told the Turkish authorities that Raphael Hostey, a 22-year-old university graduate from Manchester, was acting as a recruiter for Isis from within Syria. Hostey, who uses the nom de guerre Abu Qaqa, has been prolific on social media.
